description:
X2 is basically a short prequel to the theatrical X film. It consists of four music videos. The first three are merely stills of CLAMP's pre-1994 X artwork, but the fourth is animated by Madhouse. Being the only music video that contains actual plot, the fourth video introduces some of the major characters and quickly lashes through the first few X manga (equivalent to X TV series episodes 1-3) which take place before the theatrical movie.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Shoujo
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult females.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

node.description: [Website](http://www.clamp-net.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CLAMP_news) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/clamp_4_official/) CLAMP is an all-female Japanese manga artist group that formed in the mid-1980s. It consists of leader [Nanase Ohkawa](https://anilist.co/staff/97292), and three artists who shift roles for each series: [Mokona](https://anilist.co/staff/100802) (もこな), [Tsubaki Nekoi](https://anilist.co/staff/100804), and Satsuki Igarashi (いがらし寒月). Almost 100 million CLAMP tankōbon copies have been sold worldwide as of October 2007. In general, Ohkawa gets her inspiration for the group from everyday events such as dreams or the news. Unlike most manga artists who specialize in a single genre, CLAMP has created a diverse body of work. CLAMP's genres vary widely, from childish and comedic (Cardcaptor Sakura, Clamp School Detectives) to more dramatic and teen-rated (xxxHolic, X) series. Furthermore, drawing from the idea of Osamu Tezuka's Star System as they did in Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, CLAMP often crossover characters from their own series into their other works, which gives rise to a loosely defined "Clamp Universe".

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1521695330)

Currently working as a freelancer, having previously worked for [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) and [D.A.S.T.](https://anilist.co/studio/6255/)

Yuuki graduated from Saitama Prefectural Toda Shoyo High School and has been active in the school's "Manga and Anime Research Interest Club.” He found business in the National Health Insurance but couldn't give up on being an animator, so he left and became an animator instead. Has collaborated with director [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/) many times, including on his most famous work, [The Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/).

He works on doujinshi under the circles The Man in the High Castle and Ubik, both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick. The published doujinshi include key animation from his body of work and specially drawn manga. On the other hand, since he worked on Ralphilia Saga by [Akara Arisato](https://anilist.co/staff/149449/), he has been involved in several works as a guest member of the doujin circle La Moon.

Shigeyuki Hayashi, better known by his pseudonym Rintarou, is a well-known anime director.

A film buff ever since he was a kid, he wanted to pursue a career in filmmaking. After having worked as a cel painter in commercial animation, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) in 1958 for a brief time working on films such as [Hakujaden](https://anilist.co/anime/4513/) and [Saiyuuki](https://anilist.co/anime/4481/). After having been told that he couldn't work as a director due to not being a college graduate, he moved to [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) - making his directorial debut as one of the regular episode directors on [Tetsuwan Atom](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/).

In 1972, Rintarou left Mushi Pro to go freelance and to co-found [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11) together with [Masao Maruyama](https://anilist.co/staff/103170/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/). A few years later, Rintarou got invited to direct [Jetter Mars](https://anilist.co/anime/6087/) at his previously disinterested workplace, Toei Animation. He accepted the offer but didn't join the studio as an employee, making him one of the few people who've directed for the studio while not being an inhouse employee. He continued to direct multiple entries for Toei, including [Arrow Emblem](https://anilist.co/anime/3800/), [Captain Harlock](https://anilist.co/anime/1000/), as well as the 1979 film [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1301/), which is still considered by many as his best work.

[Haruki Kadokawa](https://anilist.co/staff/170354/), the president of [Kadokawa Shoten](https://anilist.co/studio/113/), took notice of the commercial success of Rintarou's works and hired him to direct [Genma Taisen](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/), which was the very first film produced by Kadokawa. The animation production was handled by Madhouse, where Rintarou changed his post at this time. There he continued his directorial efforts with numerous films and OVA series.

The older brother of [Masayuki Hayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/161046/).

[Official Website](http://www.xjapan.com/index.html) | [Twiter](https://twitter.com/xjapanofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/xjapanofficial/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/XJapan)

X Japan is the most successful rock group in Japanese history. Led by composer, drummer, and pianist Yoshiki, the band has sold more than 30 million albums, singles, and videos combined, sold out Japan’s 55,000-seat Tokyo Dome 18 times, and played to millions of fans around the world. In the band’s early days, their look and sound sparked a global interest in the Japanese cultural rock phenomenon “Visual-Kei”, a movement X Japan pioneered that spread worldwide.

In 1997, at the height of their success, the band broke up. Four months later, Hide, X Japan’s original lead guitarist, was found dead in his Tokyo apartment. At his funeral, more than 50,000 fans came to mourn his passing. In early 2007, Yoshiki and vocalist Toshl reunited, and later that year X Japan officially reformed.


__Members:__
• [**YOSHIKI**](https://anilist.co/staff/115552) - Yoshiki Hayashi [林佳樹] (b. Nov 20, 1965) – drums, piano, keyboard (1982–1997, 2007–present)
•  **Toshl** - Toshimitsu Deyama [出山利三] (b. Oct 10, 1965) – lead vocals, acoustic guitar, occasional drums (1982–1997, 2007–present)
•  **PATA** - Tomoaki Ishizuka [石塚智昭] (b. Nov 4, 1965) – guitar, backing vocals (1987–1997, 2007–present)
•  [**SUGIZO**](https://anilist.co/staff/156648/SUGIZO) - Yuune Sugihara [杉原有音] (b. Jul 8, 1969) – violin, guitar (2009–present) *as a touring musician* (2008–2009)
• [**HIDE**](https://anilist.co/staff/102199)\* - Hideto Matsumoto [松本秀人] (Dec 13, 1964 - May 2, 1998) – guitar, backing vocals (1987–1997; died 1998)
• **TAIJI**\* - Taiji Sawada [沢田泰司] (Jul 12, 1966 - Jul 17, 2011) – bass guitar, backing vocals (1985, 1986–1992; died 2011)
• [**HEATH**](https://anilist.co/staff/177204) - Hiroshi Morie [森江博] (Jan 22, 1968 - Oct 29, 2023) - bass (1992–1997, 2007–2023; his death)


__Former Members:__
• **TERRY** - Yuji Izumisawa [泉沢裕二] – guitar (1982–1985, died 2002)
• **TOMO** - Tomoyuki Ogata [オガタトモユキ] – guitar (1984–1985)
• **ATSUSHI** - Atsushi Tokuo [德應淳] – bass guitar (1984–1985)
• **EDDIE** - Kenichi Koide [小出健一] – guitar (1985)
• **HALLY** - Yoshifumi Yoshida [吉田良文] – guitar (1985)
• **JUN/SHU** - Hisashi Takai [高井寿] – guitar (1985, 1986)
• **ZEN/XENON** - Kazuaki Mita [三田一光] – guitar (1985–1986)
• **HIKARU** - Hikaru Utaka [宇高光] – bass guitar (1985–1986)
• **KERRY** - Masanori Takahashi [高橋雅則] – guitar (1986)
• **SATORU** - Satoru Inoue (井上悟, Inoue Satoru) – guitar (1986)
• **ISAO** - Isao Hori (堀功, Hori Isao) – guitar (1987)

\*Although Hide and Taiji are deceased, the band still considers them members and introduces them at every concert, with the group going as far as to play audio/video clips of their voice/guitar for some songs.

[Official Site](https://jp.yoshiki.net/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/yoshikiofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yoshikiofficial/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@Yoshiki/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/YoshikiOfficial)

__Birthplace:__ Tateyama, Chiba, Japan

Japanese musician, songwriter, and producer. He is best known as leader and co-founder of the band [X Japan](https://anilist.co/staff/102381), for which he is the drummer, pianist and principal songwriter.

[Official Site](https://jp.yoshiki.net/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/yoshikiofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yoshikiofficial/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@Yoshiki/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/YoshikiOfficial)

__Birthplace:__ Tateyama, Chiba, Japan

Japanese musician, songwriter, and producer. He is best known as leader and co-founder of the band [X Japan](https://anilist.co/staff/102381), for which he is the drummer, pianist and principal songwriter.
